images.copyright: Coll d'Ares, Catalan Pyrenees (© CRISTIAN IONUT ZAHARIA/Shutterstock)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Coll d'Ares, Catalan Pyrenees
images.desc: For those who appreciate quiet escapes and unspoiled nature, Coll d'Ares in the Catalan Pyrenees is a perfect place to visit. Located between Molló in Catalonia's Ripollès region and Prats-de-Mollo-la-Preste in Occitania, this pass offers a breathtaking natural spectacle, especially in winter when its landscapes are blanketed in snow. This mountain pass has served as a key route for centuries, linking the regions of Catalonia and France. Historically, it was used by traders and travellers crossing the Pyrenees, adding to its charm as a place rich in stories.

og.title: Coll d'Ares, Catalan Pyrenees

images.copyright: Humpback whale mother and calf, Tonga (© Chase Dekker/Minden Pictures)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Humpback whale mother and calf
images.desc: In today's image, we witness a humpback whale mother and calf in the waters of Tonga. Humpbacks can grow up to 12 metres long and weigh as much as 36,000 kilograms, approximately. They have a unique body shape with long flippers that can be up to one-third of their body length and special bumps called tubercles on their heads.

images.copyright: Icicles of Misotsuchi, Chichibu, Japan (© watayu0821/shutterstock)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Icicles of Misotsuchi, Chichibu, Japan
images.desc: Behold, the magic of the Misotsuchi Icicles in Chichibu, Japan! This breathtaking natural ice wall, over 30 metres wide and 10 metres tall, is formed by spring water freezing as it trickles down a rock face. The attraction, called 'Misotsuchi no Tsurara,' is only open from mid-January through mid-February and includes coloured lights after dark, creating a scene that feels straight out of a winter fairy tale.

og.title: Icicles of Misotsuchi, Chichibu, Japan

images.copyright: Two Magellanic penguins, Falkland Islands (© Vicki Jauron, Babylon and Beyond Photography/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Magellanic penguins
images.copyrightonly: © Vicki Jauron, Babylon and Beyond Photography/Getty Images
images.desc: Today's image features a couple of Magellanic penguins, photographed holding flippers in the Falkland Islands. These penguins, found in coastal Patagonia, are known for their distinctive black and white bands and their loud, braying calls. They also mate with the same partner every year. They dig burrows near the coast to lay their eggs and raise their chicks. The male returns to burrows he used the year before and waits for his partner, who can recognise him by his voice alone. Their diet mainly consists of small fish, squid and krill. They can dive up to 50 metres depth to forage for food. In winter, they migrate north to warmer waters, sometimes reaching as far as southern Brazil. These penguins are highly social and often seen in large colonies, where they communicate with each other through their distinctive calls. Fun fact: Penguins can drink seawater because they have a special gland that filters out the salt!

og.title: Magellanic penguins
og.desc: Today's image features a couple of Magellanic penguins, photographed holding flippers in the Falkland Islands. These penguins, found in…

images.copyright: Lake Tyrrell, Victoria, Australia (© Monica Bertolazzi/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Lake Tyrrell, Victoria, Australia
images.desc: At Lake Tyrrell, southern Australia, the sky meets the Earth in a dazzling display. The state of Victoria's largest salt lake was formed around 120,000 years ago. Over time, climate change caused water levels to drop; these days, the lake is normally dry, except in winter when it's covered in around 5 centimetres of water. The name 'Tyrrell' comes from the local Wergaia word for 'sky,' a nod to the Boorong Aboriginal People's interest in astronomy. Spanning more than 18,000 hectares, Lake Tyrrell is a haven for wildlife, including Mallee reptiles, kangaroos and emus.

og.title: Lake Tyrrell, Victoria, Australia
og.desc: At Lake Tyrrell, southern Australia, the sky meets the Earth in a dazzling display. The state of Victoria's largest salt lake was formed…

images.copyright: Marine iguanas, Galápagos Islands, Ecuador (© helovi/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Marine iguanas, Galápagos Islands, Ecuador
images.desc: Marine iguanas, seen in today's image, are fascinating creatures found exclusively on the Galápagos Islands in Ecuador. They weigh around 1.5 kilograms and can grow up to 1.5 metres in length. These reptiles are the only lizards in the world that forage in the sea, diving to graze on algae growing on submerged rocks. Researchers believe that both Galápagos land iguanas and marine iguanas evolved from a common ancestor that likely rafted from Central or South America. They've adapted in remarkable ways, from flattened tails for swimming to salt glands that allow them to expel seawater by sneezing.

og.title: Marine iguanas, Galápagos Islands, Ecuador

images.copyright: Yungang Grottoes, Datong, Shanxi province, China (© Eric Yang/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Yungang Grottoes, Datong, China
images.desc: What do 51,000 ancient statues have in common? They all call the Yungang Grottoes in China home! This masterpiece of early Buddhist art is near Datong in Shanxi province, northeastern China. Carved into sandstone cliffs over 1,500 years ago during the Northern Wei dynasty (386–534/535 CE), the grottoes contain 254 caves. The highlight is the massive Buddha in Cave 5, which is a jaw-dropping 17 metres tall. But don't stop there—each cave offers something unique. Some are like ancient storyboards, depicting tales from Buddhist scriptures, while others showcase detailed carvings of monks, deities, musician and even scenes of daily life under Wei rule.

og.title: Yungang Grottoes, Datong, China

images.copyright: Art installation of umbrellas, Borough Market, London, England (© Malcolm P Chapman/Getty Images)
images.title: Info
images.caption: Art Installation of umbrellas, London, England
images.desc: Today's image features one of the simplest yet most essential inventions in human history: the umbrella, or parasol. Over 4,000 years ago, in ancient Egypt, Assyria and China, these foldable canopies were first used to shield people from the sun. It wasn't until the 17th century that the umbrella, as we know it today, gained popularity in Europe, initially as a luxury item primarily for women. Fast-forward a few centuries and these weather shields have become a staple in pop culture, too. Remember Mary Poppins with her iconic umbrella that helped her fly, or Rihanna's hit song 'Umbrella'?
